how can I mount an image made with parti: mount -o loop -t <filesystem> <image> <mountpoint>
it was a fat32 filesystem. when I use -t vfat, I receive: bad superblock. the partimage file was decompressed with unp. any idea?
I'm not familiar with partimage.  Is this a partitioned filesystem image?  Does it contain partitions within it, or is it just a flat filesystem image?
If there are partitions within the image, you need to supply an offset.
just a flat filesystem. are you german?
Not usually.
If it is partitioned, you need to specify an offset.  See:  http://www.unix.com/filesystems-disks-memory/24366-can-loopback-filesystem-partitioned.html
... I've run into that with qemu disk images (as deckard did in that post).
If the image is compressed, yes, you'll have to uncompress it.
Just reading partimage docs.
... and I think it compresses by default.  Unless there's a loopback compressed filesystem driver/module, you'll have to decompress the file yourself.

when I gzip -d image.dat.gz, I receive a file image.dat, however when I type in file image.dat I receive: (...) fat16 device /dev/sde, original filename backup_sd_1gb.img, gzip compressed     why is image.dat still gzipped?
Not sure.  You might try looking at the first few hundred bytes with a hex editor.  Or:  dd if=image.dat bs=512 count=1 | od -c | less

... which dumps the first 512 bytes.  IIRC 'file' is looking at the first 1024 (max) bytes of a file to work out what it is.  It's guessing, might be wrong, may have found a gzip header within the disk image.
Try mounting the file yourself.
RTFM ;-)
dd if=/dev/zero of=filePart.part bs=1000k count=1000 && losetup /dev/loop0 filePart.part && partimage restore /dev/loop0 image.img.gz && mount /dev/loop0 /mnt
Success?
There you go ;-)
thanks ;)
